course.subject: HUMA
course.name: Cultures and Values: Language, Communication and Society
course.description: Languages are considered complex repositories of cultures, where meanings are created and articulated, verbally and non-verbally, about the artefacts, norms, beliefs, and values of cultures. Language use, an integral part of human communication, mirrors the inextricably entangled psychological, social, and cultural facets of human cognition and interaction. Building upon a fundamental exploration of the nature of human languages, this course will delve into the closely interlinked notions of language, communication and society as manifested in our daily life, in the context of globalization and increasing border-crossing and intercultural exchanges. Through a lingua-cultural lens, we will probe a range of issues rooted in language and culture: language and thought; identities, self and 'othering'; cultural diversity in verbal and nonverbal communication; language, gender and sexuality; popular culture and global cultural flow; language and power; globalization and language planning and policy in different cultural contexts. Through discussions of such, the course aims to cultivate an appreciation and respect for linguistic and cultural diversity, communicative sensitivity, and social equality.

Building upon a fundamental exploration of the nature of human languages, this course will delve into the closely interlinked notions of language, communication and society as manifested in our daily life, in the context of globalization and increasing border-crossing and intercultural exchanges. Through a lingua-cultural lens, we will probe a range of issues rooted in language and culture: language and thought; identities, self and 'othering'; cultural diversity in verbal and nonverbal communication; language, gender and sexuality; popular culture and global cultural flow; language and power; globalization and language planning and policy in different cultural contexts. Through discussions of such, the course aims to cultivate an appreciation and respect for linguistic and cultural diversity, communicative sensitivity, and social equality.

Topics covered are appropriate for 1000-level HUMA, in that the materials are not abstruse in nature (unlike some other 2/3000-level HUMAs which demand philosophical thinking towards lengthy pieces of reading materials). It is good that Cathy includes useful examples and case studies whenever she illustrates important concepts.

It is particularly interesting that Nineteen Eighty-Four is reviewed and analyzed from a socio-linguistic perspective. In the past, I would only appreciate it as a literary masterpiece that satires totalitarianism. So I would say this course really inspires me to interpret the novel from a new angle.

60% of the score remains unknown. You will never know which part(s) you flunked out when your final grade sucks.

The good thing is that Cathy allowed students who performed unsatisfactorily in quiz 1 to sign up the timed online quiz 2, and both quizzes will be counted. I only got 13/16 in quiz 1 (mean is 12.7, while max is 17 becoz of a bonus question) so I decided to take the online quiz. The quiz was extremely hard, in that almost every question refers to the exact wordings of one particular ppt slide, and the time allowed was very tight. Fortunately, I still managed to get full score in the quiz.

Grading is pretty good overall. I have studied some other 2000-level HUMA before and ended up a B. In this course, comparatively, I could get an A. After all, the quality of your term essay remains the determining factor of your final grade. Though, if you desire an A+, you should aim at full score for both quizzes. With the same quality of term essay, what differentiates an A+ from an A is the subtle difference in quiz results.
